entry.title: Extending an SAP Sample Sankey Custom Widget in SAP Analytics Cloud to Deliver Top-N Hierarchical In
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) does not provide a native, built-in Sankey chart as part of its standard visualization catalog. As a result, Sankey-style visualizations in SAC are typically implemented using custom widgets.

In mid-2024, while working on an enterprise analytics engagement, I encountered a requirement to visualize:

  • Top N parent entities (for example, service providers)
  • And, for each parent, the Top M child entities independently ranked per parent (for example, services offered)

All of this needed to be displayed within a single Sankey visualization, enabling users to immediately understand concentration and distribution patterns without navigating multiple charts.

To address this requirement, I explored SAC‚Äôs Custom Widget framework and extended an existing SAP-provided sample Sankey custom widget into a production-ready solution.

I have intentionally included the development and deployment steps in detail so that consultants or developers who are completely new to Sankey custom widgets in SAP Analytics Cloud can deploy and validate the solution end-to-end by following this blog.

SAP Sample Sankey Custom Widget as the Starting Point

Since SAP Analytics Cloud does not include a native Sankey chart, I referred to a sample Sankey custom widget implementation shared by SAP through the SAP Community. This SAP-provided sample demonstrates how a Sankey diagram can be rendered using the SAC Custom Widget framework and served as a technical starting point for my work.

The SAP sample was very helpful as a technical reference, as it illustrated:

  • Custom widget structure and lifecycle
  • Binding SAC model data to a widget
  • Rendering a Sankey diagram using JavaScript

During mid-2024, while actively working on this requirement, I engaged in the comments section of that SAP Community blog (SAP Analytics Cloud: Custom Widget & Widget Add-Ons Samples Preview) under my SAP Community user@GovindaRaoBanothu45 , discussing feasibility and implementation boundaries.

While the sample clarified the basic rendering approach, it also highlighted functional gaps when applied to enterprise-scale analytical requirements.

Why the SAP Sample Sankey Widget Was Not Sufficient

The SAP-provided Sankey custom widget was intentionally designed as a generic sample. Its behavior was to render all nodes and all links returned by the bound dataset.

However, the sample widget did not support the enterprise analytical requirement I was addressing, specifically:

  • No Top-N filtering at the parent level
  • No independent ranking of child nodes per parent
  • No data trimming prior to Sankey rendering
  • Limited usability for large, real-world datasets

As a result, while the SAP sample demonstrated how to render a Sankey chart, it did not meet the analytical or usability needs of an enterprise dashboard.

This gap required extending and enhancing the SAP sample Sankey custom widget with additional, original logic to reshape the dataset before rendering.

High-Level Architecture of the Extended Sankey Widget

The Sankey rendering mechanism remains aligned with the SAP sample, while the data-transformation layer represents the core extension.

Development Environment and Prerequisites

Prerequisites

To get started, ensure that you have:

  • Access to SAP Analytics Cloud with Optimized Design Experience enabled
  • Node.js installed on your local machine
  • Visual Studio Code (VS Code) installed
  • Basic understanding of JavaScript and JSON

Development Environment Setup

Install Node.js

  1. Download Node.js from: https://nodejs.org
  2. Verify installation:
node -v
npm -v

Install Visual Studio Code

  1. Download VS Code from: https://code.visualstudio.com
  2. Use VS Code as the primary editor for developing and maintaining the custom widget files.

Set Up the Project Folder

  1. Create a project folder (for example, SankeySAPcode).
  2. Open the folder in Visual Studio Code.
  3. Create the following files:
  • main.js ‚Äì core widget logic and Sankey rendering
  • index.json ‚Äì metadata and resource configuration
  • hash256.js ‚Äì Node.js script for integrity key generation

Sankey Custom Widget ‚Äì Standard Project Structure

For the standard Sankey implementation, I created a dedicated project folder (for example, SankeySAPcode or any relevant project name). This folder contains all the supporting and required files needed to build and deploy the Sankey custom widget in SAP Analytics Cloud.

The project folder includes:

  • main.js
    The web component JavaScript file that contains the core widget logic and Sankey rendering code (mandatory).
  • index.json
    The metadata file that defines the custom widget, its properties, and resource references (mandatory).
  • sankeyChartStyling.js
    An optional styling component used to expose styling options in the widget‚Äôs styling panel (optional).
  • build/ folder
    Contains the helper script hash256.js, which is used to generate SHA-256 integrity keys for the JavaScript files.

Note: Styling files (Styling.js, sankeyChartStyling.js, or xxxxStyling.js) are optional and may not be required for all custom widgets.
However, the web component JavaScript file (main.js or equivalent) and the metadata file (index.json) are mandatory for every SAP Analytics Cloud custom widget. The build folder is included purely for maintainability and ease of understanding.
Technically, the hash256.js file can also be placed directly in the main project folder. Including it in a separate subfolder is optional and does not impact deployment, as long as the final ZIP file complies with SAP Analytics Cloud‚Äôs upload requirements.

Creating Integrity Keys and Deploying the Code

SAP Analytics Cloud supports SHA-256 integrity validation to ensure uploaded JavaScript resources are not modified.

Generating Integrity Keys

  1. Open a Node.js command prompt
  2. Navigate to the folder containing hash256.js
  3. Execute the script

Example output:

  • main.js: sha256-6134FFLCQYpH7x8gx29H1xJyRbitpf/guj5UGKhJ25Q=
  • sankeyChartStyling.js:  sha256-AR0uDO+9h8nu9EyJotSinZ2APDWD5Ja2JmdFcZCH1Xo=

Note: If additional JavaScript resource files are included, their corresponding sha256- integrity keys must also be added to the index.json file under the resources section.

Similarly, the file names must be updated in hash256.js before generating integrity keys for those files.

Core Enhancement: Top-N Parent and Top-M Child Logic

The following snippets are representative excerpts from the working implementation.
Full scripts are intentionally not published, as this widget was delivered as part of an enterprise engagement.

In the widget, the SAC data binding is first normalized into an array (data) containing parent node, child node, and measure value fields.

Step 1: Aggregate Measure by Parent

const parentTotals = {};
data.forEach(row => {
  parentTotals[row.parentNode] =
    (parentTotals[row.parentNode] || 0) + Number(row.measureValue);
});

Step 2: Rank and Retain Top-N Parents

const topParents = Object.entries(parentTotals)
  .sort((a, b) => b[1] - a[1])
  .slice(0, TOP_N_PARENT_NODES)
  .map(entry => entry[0]);

Step 3: Rank and Retain Top-M Children per Parent

const filteredLinks = [];
topParents.forEach(parent => {
  const children = data
    .filter(row => row.parentNode === parent)
    .sort((a, b) => b.measureValue - a.measureValue)
    .slice(0, TOP_N_CHILD_NODES);

  children.forEach(child => {
    filteredLinks.push({
      source: parent,
      target: child.childNode,
      value:  child.measureValue
    });
  });
});

Step 4: Rebuild Nodes

const nodes = [...new Set(
  filteredLinks.flatMap(l => [l.source, l.target])
)].map(name => ({ name }));

Step 5: Render Sankey

sankey.nodes(nodes).links(filteredLinks).layout(32);

The rendering follows the SAP sample approach; the innovation lies in the data-transformation logic.

Once all required files and script updates are ready, let‚Äôs deploy the custom widget into SAP Analytics Cloud.

Deploy the Custom Widget

  1. Create a ZIP File:
    • Include main.js, index.json, and optional styling files in a .zip file.
  2. Upload to SAP Analytics Cloud:
    • Navigate to the Custom Widgets section in SAC.
    • Upload the .json and .zip files.
  3. Test the Widget:
    • Add the custom widget to a story and configure data sources.

Select the JSON metadata file from your local system.

Next, select the resource file that is .zip file of main.js, index.json and styling.js or any other file related to this chart.

Now you can the widget in "Custom Widgets" section.

Observe the warning messages below with and/without integrity checks in the list of custom widgets

We have done custom widget deployment and will use the same in stories. Let's see how to access this in story 2.0.

 

From the builder panel, select your data model, set measure, set a hierarchical dimension and edit the default colors of the different depths from the Styling panel.

Below screenshot show the usage of the Styling.JS file.

This incremental approach helped validate correctness before applying the logic to larger Top-N configurations.

Acknowledgment

I would like to thank @marouferchichi for actively engaging in the SAP Community blog comments and helping clarify the capabilities and boundaries of the sample Sankey custom widget.

The final implementation described here represents my independent extension and delivery of that sample to meet enterprise-level analytical requirements.

Conclusion

This blog demonstrates how a SAP sample Sankey custom widget can be extended into a production-grade Top-N hierarchical Sankey visualization using SAP Analytics Cloud‚Äôs Custom Widget framework.

For similar enterprise scenarios, this approach provides a reusable and scalable pattern.

entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP HANA Cloud ‚Äì December 2025
entry.content:
As the year draws to a close and the holiday season is approaching, we‚Äôre excited to share one more set of updates before 2025 wraps up. The Q4 release of SAP HANA Cloud delivers a focused set of innovations designed to further improve operational efficiency, resilience, developer productivity, and more.

Let‚Äôs deep dive into key innovations included in the December 2025 release:

 

SQL Tools for Administration in SAP HANA Cloud Central

Property Graph Viewer in Database Administration Tooling

With the Q4 release, SAP HANA Cloud Central introduces a property graph viewer directly within the database administration tooling. This viewer allows you to visually explore property graphs, where entities are represented as vertices and relationships as edges. A common example is modeling airports as vertices and flight routes as directed edges, including properties such as distance. You can apply filters to vertices and edges and enhance their analysis by applying built-in graph algorithms like neighborhood exploration, shortest path, or Cypher-based filtering.

The main value of the property graph viewer is faster understanding of complex relationships stored in graph structures. Instead of relying on raw query results, you can visually explore how entities are connected and quickly identify patterns, dependencies, or anomalies. This makes graph data more accessible not only to technical experts but also to solution architects and analysts who benefit from an intuitive, visual representation of relationships.

SQL Console Background Activities

SQL console background activities enable long-running SQL statements to continue executing independently of the browser session. You can now start a statement, close the browser, and return later to review the results without interrupting execution. This capability is fully integrated into the database administration tooling in SAP HANA Cloud Central.

This feature removes a long-standing friction point when working with complex or time-consuming SQL workloads. Administrators and developers no longer need to keep browser sessions open or worry about accidental disconnects. As a result, productivity increases, and operational tasks such as data preparation, analysis, or maintenance queries become more reliable and less disruptive.

Automatic Saving and Loading of SQL Statements

The SQL console now automatically saves its contents and connection details and restores them when you return. This behavior can be configured in the settings, allowing you to decide how persistent their SQL console sessions should be.

This enhancement provides continuity when switching tasks or sessions. You can pick up exactly where you left off, without re-establishing connections or recovering lost SQL statements. It improves day-to-day efficiency and reduces context switching, especially for administrators and developers working across multiple systems.

Application for Schemas and Deployment Infrastructure Containers

A new application in the database administration tooling provides a consolidated view of schemas and SAP HANA deployment infrastructure (HDI) containers within a subaccount. These can optionally be grouped by their associated SAP HANA database instance. You can examine detailed metadata, including Cloud Foundry organization and space information, instance IDs, and links to the associated database. From there, you can directly navigate to the database instance or open a SQL Console or database explorer connection.

This application simplifies landscape transparency for administrators. Instead of piecing together information across tools, you can quickly identify where schemas and containers live, understand their context, and jump directly into analysis or troubleshooting. This is especially valuable in larger environments with many applications and database instances.

 

Multi-Model and Machine Learning Updates

With the Q4 2025 release of SAP HANA Cloud, we continue to strengthen embedded Machine Learning and AI capabilities across the Predictive Analysis Library (PAL), the Automated Predictive Library (APL), and the Natural Language Processing (NLP) Services. These enhancements focus on making advanced analytics easier to use, more consistent across scenarios, and better suited for real-world business data.

Key highlights of this release are:

  • A new unified time series procedure, serving developers to utilize the same interface across different times series algorithms
  • text embedding model enhancements, supporting output vector dimensionality reduction, while maintaining retrieval accuracy
  • a new cross encoder model with the NLP services, for accurately re-ranking search results
  • text column input, text embedding operators with AutoML classification and regression models
  • text tokenization enhancements supporting regular expression token filtering and a new text log parsing function for detecting and determining new log pattern
  • the HANA ML experiment monitor UI now supports visual model monitoring and drift analysis

To learn more about the new Multi-Model and Machine Learning updates, check out @ChristophMorgen‚Äòs blogpost here.

Transforming Property Graphs into Knowledge Graphs

With the Q4 2025 release, SAP HANA Cloud introduces the ability to transform property graphs into knowledge graphs. This capability allows you to convert existing graph structures into a semantic, knowledge-graph representation without redesigning your data models from scratch. It enables you to work with different graph paradigms on top of the same underlying data.

This innovation helps you maximize data utility by seamlessly switching between property graph and knowledge graph models depending on your needs. You are no longer restricted to a single data representation and can choose the most appropriate graph model for analytics, reasoning, or integration scenarios. As a result, you gain greater operational efficiency, improved interoperability between graph models, and more flexibility in how you explore and reuse graph-based data.

Learn more about transforming property graphs into knowledge graphs on this blogpost by @shabana .

 

Calculation View Modeling Updates

Column Lineage Insights for Graphical Calculation Views

SAP HANA Cloud now allows you to gain column lineage insights for graphically modeled calculation views by calling an SQL table function. This capability provides transparency into how output columns are derived from underlying sources, with lineage tracked across graphical modeling steps and stopping at functions or procedures.

By making lineage information easily accessible, this feature improves model quality and trust. Developers can better understand complex models, speed up enhancements, and reduce errors during refactoring. For architects and analysts, clearer lineage increases confidence in the data and supports governance and audit requirements.

Input Parameters for Currency and Unit Conversion in MDS Cubes

Input parameters can now be used to specify client values for currency and unit conversion when working with multidimensional services (MDS) cubes. These values no longer need to be materialized, and conversions can be defined dynamically at query runtime.

This enhancement increases flexibility in analytical scenarios. You can adapt conversions based on runtime context without redesigning models or creating additional persisted data. It enables more dynamic reporting and simplifies scenarios where conversion logic depends on user input or business context.

Restricted Columns in MDS Cubes

With Q4, restricted columns can be added to MDS cubes and evaluated at query execution time. If runtime evaluation is not possible, deployment fails with a clear notification. This approach avoids mandatory materialization of input parameters while still ensuring correctness.

The key value lies in greater runtime control and reduced data preparation overhead. You can now influence how restricted columns are processed without forcing early decisions during modeling, leading to more flexible cubes and more efficient execution.

Visibility of Key Columns When Modeling Joins

When defining joins in calculation views, key columns are now visually indicated. This makes it easier to understand join semantics and identify important relationships directly in the modeling UI.

By highlighting key columns, this feature helps you create star joins with greater confidence and accuracy. It reduces modeling errors, improves data consistency, and ultimately results in higher-quality analytical models.

Left Outer Joins in Star Joins of MDS Cubes

SAP HANA Cloud now supports left outer joins in star joins for MDS cubes. This expands the range of scenarios that can be modeled using multidimensional services.

The benefit is faster adoption of MDS cubes in additional analytical use cases. You gain more flexibility in how dimensions and facts are combined, without having to fall back to alternative modeling approaches.

If you are interested in discovering more about Calculation View modeling updates, check out this blogpost by @JanZwickel.

 

Cloud Reliability and Total Cost of Ownership

The Q4 release of SAP HANA Cloud is also introducing significant enhancements to strengthen the service's reliability while reduction the overal total cost of ownership at the same time.

Multi-Region Disaster Recovery

In early Q4 we extended disaster recovery capabilities beyond multiple availability zones within a single region to selected, distant regions. The initial scope focused on North America, using Amazon Web Services with a pairing between US East (VA) and US West (Oregon). Support includes SAP HANA Cloud Data Lake Files, while multi-tenancy is excluded in the initial phase.

This innovation significantly improves resilience against regional outages. By maintaining a secondary system in a distant region, customers can better protect critical workloads and ensure business continuity. The offering starts with a defined scope and will expand stepwise to additional regions, cloud providers, and features.

We're happy to share, that we will be extending our offering to Europe, early in January 2026. Customers will then be able to protect SAP HANA Cloud workloads across EU Central (Frankfurt) and EU South (Milan), improving resilience against regional outages with a secondary system in a predefined, geographically distant region. This expansion will help EU-based and global customers strengthen business continuity while meeting regional availability and data residency needs, with additional regions and enhancements planned based on demand.

Active/Active Read-Enabled High Availability

Synchronous replicas in a "high availability" configuration ensure increased reliability via autonomous failover capabilities to standby systems, in case of outages or other incidents.
But, such high availability setups require redundant resources, which traditionally remain idle during normal operations. With the new active/active read-enabled option, SAP HANA Cloud allows these secondary systems to actively handle read-intensive analytical workloads. In the initial scope, client-side statement routing enables applications to direct analytical queries to these replicas.

This approach improves cost efficiency and performance at the same time. You can offload analytical workloads from the primary system while still preserving full high-availability readiness. The same resources that ensure resilience now also deliver day-to-day business value.

Automatic Up-Scaling Storage

SAP HANA Cloud now supports automatic storage upscaling to prevent disk-full situations. When enabled by administrators, the system can double the initially provisioned storage size - up to a customer-defined maximum - once usage reaches 98%. Alerts notify administrators, and a minimum cycle time of six hours applies between scaling events.

This capability helps avoid critical outages caused by full disks while still keeping costs under control. Administrators gain more time to react to growing storage needs and can define clear boundaries for automatic scaling, balancing safety and predictability.

 

Seamless Integration with  SAP Business Data Cloud

As announced at SAP TechEd 2025, SAP HANA Cloud will integrate in a bi-directional manner with SAP Business Data Cloud, to consume and produce data products and thereby combine the best out of two solutions. While the production of data products will become available in early 2026, the consumption is now possible with our latest release.

Native Consumption of Data Products

SAP HANA Cloud can now directly consume data products from SAP Business Data Cloud. Virtual table connections are created automatically, enabling seamless access from SAP HANA Cloud to the data product source.

This integration allows customers to extend SAP line-of-business applications with custom logic while relying on governed, reusable data products. It reduces integration effort and accelerates innovation by making enterprise data easier to access and combine.

 

Enhancements to SQL on Files

Delta Table Replication

Direct read-only access to Delta tables in the object storage or through Delta Sharing, which has been introduced since QRC 04/2024, has offered real-time analytics on the vast volume of data in files, without moving them into SAP HANA Cloud. With QRC 04/2025, it evolves further by offering replication capability for critical datasets, enabling faster queries with greater flexibility and robust data management.

This new Delta table-to-HANA replication offers granular controls, such as chunk-based initial load, which allows splitting the data into multiple chunks and loading them separately to make the initial load more manageable. Furthermore, when it comes to Change Data Capture (CDC), it allows either user-driven, version-based CDC or system-driven, scheduled CDC for full automation. 

To learn more about SAP HANA Cloud‚Äôs new Delta table-to-HANA replication, take a look at @SeungjoonLee's blog post here.

Smart Data Access: Support for two new remote sources through Data Access Agent

Additionally, based on the newly introduced Smart Data Access (SDA) Data Access Agent from the last QRC 03/2025, read-only access to two new remote sources, Google Sheets and Oracle Database in the cloud, will be available from QRC 04/2025. 

The way of configuring and using them remains the same as for other previously supported remote sources, and for newly provisioned Data Access Agents, all new adapters are activated by default. To activate new adapters for a Data Access Agent that has already been provisioned and is currently in use, please refer to SAP Note 2600176 - SAP HANA Smart Data Access Supported Remote Sources for further details on how to activate them, as well as additional information on support. 

 

Datacenter Updates

In Q4 2025, we are announcing the availability of SAP HANA Cloud in these new BTP regions:

  • Italy (Milan) on AWS 
  • Germany (St. Leon-Rot) on SCI 
  • United Arab Emirates (Dubai) on SCI 
  • US West (Colorado) on SCI* 
  • Australia (Sydney) on SCI* 

* General availability is expected by the end of Q4 2025, when the respective BTP regions are planned to go live. See SAP Roadmap Explorer for details.

We continue our journey to give customers the freedom to choose their preferred infrastructure cloud provider by investing in regions on both hyperscalers and SAP Cloud Infrastructure (SCI). 

  • On AWS, we are announcing the availability of SAP HANA Cloud in a second European region: Italy (Milan). This establishes the technical foundation for multi-region disaster recovery within European borders. 

The first SCI region ‚Äî Germany (Frankfurt) ‚Äî was announced in Q3 2025, see blog post. Now, we are making SAP HANA Cloud available globally on SCI, by offering a second SCI region in Germany (with EU Access), as well as SCI regions in the U.S., Australia, and the UAE.

 

Further Updates

Native Multi-Tenancy: Tenant Move with Reduced Downtime

The enhanced tenant move process for SAP HANA Cloud native multi-tenancy splits the operation into a preparation phase and a short cutover phase. During preparation, tenant data is copied while the source tenant remains fully operational. Only during the final cutover is brief downtime required to apply delta changes and switch over.

This significantly reduces business downtime and gives you control over scheduling the cutover in low-impact time windows. It improves operational flexibility and minimizes risk during tenant reorganization.

Selective, Incremental Migration to SAP HANA Cloud

Selective, incremental migration allows you to migrate chosen parts of an SAP HANA 2.0 database to SAP HANA Cloud instead of moving everything at once. Migrations can be performed in smaller, manageable steps based on schemas or deployment infrastructure containers.

This approach reduces downtime, avoids migrating unused components, and makes large migrations more predictable. It allows you to better plan the transition to the cloud, while minimizing disruption.

Rule-Based Index Advisor

The new rule-based Index Advisor analyzes query usage patterns to identify index optimization opportunities. It recommends creating or dropping indexes for single-table filter queries and provides ready-to-execute SQL statements.

By automating index analysis, this feature improves performance while helping control costs. Administrators gain actionable insights without deep manual analysis, making database tuning more accessible and efficient.

Thanks for taking the time to explore the What‚Äôs New in SAP HANA Cloud on Q4 2025 innovations!

If you‚Äôd like to go deeper into the technical details of the December 2025 release, we recommend visiting the What‚Äôs New Viewer in the technical documentation. It provides a comprehensive overview of the full release scope. To stay informed about upcoming innovations, announcements, and best practices, follow the SAP HANA Cloud tag.

You can also find our latest blog posts by searching for the #whatsnewinsaphanacloud hashtag.

If you missed earlier What‚Äôs New webinars, you‚Äôll find recordings of past sessions and upcoming events in our YouTube playlist. Our What‚Äôs New webinar covering the Q4 2025 innovations will be posted on this playlist very soon.

Do you have questions about SAP HANA Cloud or want to share your thoughts on the new features?
Join the conversation in the SAP HANA Cloud Community Q&A or leave a comment below. We‚Äôd love to hear from you!

Enjoy the holidays and have a great start into 2026!

entry.title: From AI Ideas to Tangible Business Value
entry.content:
How to turn AI ambition into real traction ‚Äî with the right methodology

Artificial intelligence is firmly embedded in enterprise strategies today.
What many organizations still struggle with, however, is turning AI ambition into operational value.

Too many initiatives stall at proof-of-concept stage, create isolated solutions, or deliver impressive demos without enabling real business decisions. Over time, this erodes trust ‚Äî in technology, in delivery models, and sometimes even in IT leadership.
The key question is therefore no longer ‚ÄúWhat could we do with AI?‚Äù
It is:

How do we move from a real business problem to a confident go / no-go decision ‚Äî quickly, responsibly, and with the organization on board?

Why this matters now

AI is no longer an innovation topic. It is a leadership and transformation topic.

Today, AI initiatives compete with limited organizational change capacity, ongoing cloud transformations, rising expectations from business leaders, and increasing pressure to deliver visible results.

The real risk is not moving too slowly.
It is moving fast in the wrong direction ‚Äî creating fragmented solutions, undermining trust, or introducing AI faster than the organization can absorb it.

What companies need now is not more experimentation, but a repeatable way to turn AI ideas into informed decisions, aligned with enterprise standards and grounded in real business needs.

Problem first ‚Äî not technology first

Successful AI use cases do not start with models, tools, or platforms.
They start with concrete business pain points: high manual effort, lack of transparency, time pressure in critical phases, or uncertainty in decision-making.

This is exactly where proven innovation approaches such as the SAP AppHaus come in. The focus is on understanding and framing the problem first, prioritizing what really matters ‚Äî and only then discussing solutions.

This shift sounds simple, but it fundamentally changes outcomes.

Humanize, visualize and validate with Scenes from SAP AppHaus

From idea to decision: rapid prototyping with SAP Mode 2 Garage

The examples below were implemented using the SAP Mode 2 Garage.

A Mode 2 Garage is a highly focused, time-boxed format in which customers work together with SAP to analyze a concrete business problem, define clear goals and success criteria, build a working prototype, and create a solid decision basis for next steps.

Methodologically, the Mode 2 Garage combines AppHaus principles ‚Äî problem focus, user centricity, co-innovation ‚Äî with hands-on implementation together with SAP Services, the customer, and end users.

The outcome is not a concept.
It is clarity.

Two example use cases from practice

Use case 1: AI-supported user guidance in procurement

In large organizations, many procurement needs arise outside the daily routine ‚Äî often from people who do not regularly work with procurement processes. These needs are not necessarily complex, but they are unfamiliar.

Typical situations include one-time service requests, non-catalog purchases, questions around existing framework agreements, or time-critical requests with limited process knowledge.

As a result, procurement teams face high manual effort, inconsistent data quality, and avoidable delays ‚Äî not because functionality is missing, but because guidance is missing at the moment of need.

Implementation approach (high level)

The prototype was built around a chat-based user interface on the SAP Business Technology Platform, serving as a central entry point for users.

A custom chatbot captured requests in natural language. Uploaded quotations and documents were analyzed and grounded with enterprise context using the SAP GenAI Hub. Instead of generating generic answers, AI responses were enriched with structured enterprise knowledge. Relevant SAP backend systems were integrated to retrieve information such as applicable framework agreements, category-specific rules, approval thresholds, and historical purchasing patterns.

Critical decision points remained explicitly human-in-the-loop. AI was positioned as guidance and decision support ‚Äî not automation.

The solution was implemented modularly, extensible, and aligned with standard processes.

Outcome and time-to-value

Even at prototype stage, the solution delivered tangible value: fewer follow-up questions to procurement, improved data quality at the point of request, and higher user acceptance through guided interaction.

Based on clear decision readiness, the solution was further developed and went live in less than one year.
The prototype did not just validate an idea ‚Äî it became the springboard into productive use.

Outlook

Looking ahead, this approach is well suited to be integrated into SAP Joule as a custom-built Joule skill, embedding AI-supported procurement guidance directly into daily workflows while retaining full control over enterprise context, governance, and process logic.

Use case 2: AI-supported GR/IR reconciliation in finance closing

Although the company was already running on SAP S/4HANA, GR/IR reconciliation was still largely handled in the traditional SAP GUI way. Transparency on open cases was limited, analysis effort was high, and closing periods were stressful for finance and procurement alike.

The challenge was not missing functionality, but handling complexity efficiently and consistently.

Step 1: Standard first

The first deliberate step was not AI, but the introduction of the standard GR/IR Monitoring and Reconciliation Fiori app. This alone improved transparency, established a shared working basis, and clarified ownership across teams.

Step 2: Targeted AI extension

Building on the standard, a complementary custom Fiori app was prototyped to address the hard cases: unmatched GR/IR positions, unclear root causes, and high manual clarification effort.

SAP standard remained the system of record. AI was applied selectively where complexity arose. Document AI analyzed invoices and supporting documents, while generative AI summarized context and suggested next best actions. Importantly, AI did not post accounting entries ‚Äî it supported expert decision-making by structuring information and proposing options.

Positioning towards the SAP standard

Comparable capabilities will increasingly become available through embedded AI capabilities and SAP Joule as part of SAP‚Äôs roadmap. In this case, however, Joule was not yet an option due to missing cloud readiness in the current system landscape.

The prototype therefore deliberately served as a bridge to the standard ‚Äî delivering short-term value, enabling organizational learning, and preparing for future adoption of standard SAP capabilities, without creating a long-term parallel solution.

Current status

Around six months after the prototype, the use case is in business testing and validation, with a strong focus on trust, plausibility, and acceptance.

The biggest challenge is not AI ‚Äî it's change

Across both use cases, one insight stood out clearly: the biggest hurdle is not technology, data, or architecture ‚Äî it is change management.

For readers who want to dive deeper into AI concepts such as grounding, document AI, or retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), SAP provides a comprehensive reference with its AI Best Practices on SAP BTP.

In practice, however, success depended less on technology and more on how people adapted. Introducing AI changes how users trust recommendations, interact with systems, make decisions, and let go of familiar routines.

Rapid prototyping played a crucial role by creating a safe learning environment ‚Äî allowing teams to build confidence before scaling.

Key takeaways

  • AI initiatives need a decision goal, not just a technical objective

  • Standard-first approaches build trust and accelerate adoption

  • Prototypes create value when they enable organizational learning

  • Change management must start on day one

  • AI succeeds when people become comfortable using it

Conclusion: methodology beats actionism

AI does not fail because of technology.
It fails when organizations move faster than their people.

Clear methodology, rapid prototyping, and early change management are what turn AI from strategic intent into operational value.

entry.title: SAP BTP - Integration Advisor - (MIG & MAG) from a CPI Developer Perspective
entry.content:
Hello Hello,

Introduction:

In this blog, I would like to share my hands-on experience using SAP Integration Advisor  based on independent exploration and practical experimentation.

The primary focus will be on Message Implementation Guidelines (MIG) and Mapping Guidelines (MAG).

I will also briefly touch on the technology platform context, specifically SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP), with the scope strictly limited to integration-related services. Topics such as analytics, artificial intelligence, automation, and application development are intentionally out of scope for this blog.

At the end of the blog, I will include a set of reference materials that supported my learning journey. That said, the majority of the insights and conclusions shared here are derived from direct, hands-on experience rather than theoretical examples.

Technology Platform:

First, let‚Äôs start with the Technology Platform. What does that really mean?

A technology platform is the basic foundation that allows software to run. It is made up of different layers that work together, including infrastructure (hardware, memory, storage, databases), the operating system (Windows, Linux), runtime environments, security and networking, and the software layer itself ‚Äî such as databases, web applications, mobile apps, and IoT solutions.

In simple terms, a technology platform provides everything needed to build, run, and secure applications.

SAP BTP (SAP Business Technology Platform)

SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) is SAP‚Äôs cloud-based platform-as-a-service (PaaS) that enables organizations to extend, integrate, and innovate across SAP and non-SAP systems in a secure and upgrade-safe way.

As mentioned earlier, the image below highlights the four technology pillars supported by SAP BTP. That said, in this blog we will focus only on the integration pillar, specifically SAP Integration Suite.

What is SAP Integration Suite?

SAP Integration Suite is SAP‚Äôs cloud-based integration platform used to connect SAP and non-SAP systems, both in the cloud and on-premise, in a secure, scalable, and standardized way.

  • Cloud Integration ‚Äì Core component for end-to-end integrations
  • Integration Advisor ‚Äì Used mainly for B2B and EDI scenarios
  • API Management ‚Äì Expose, secure, and manage APIs
  • Open Connectors ‚Äì Prebuilt connectors for third-party applications
  • Event Mesh - The event-driven backbone 

OK, we‚Äôve already talked about the technology platform, explored SAP BTP, explored the cloud types of service and walked through SAP Integration Suite and its components.

Now comes the most important part of this blog ‚Äî Integration Advisor. So let‚Äôs dive in and start this journey together.

What is SAP Integration Advisor?

SAP Integration Advisor is a capability within SAP Integration Suite, primarily designed for B2B and EDI-based integrations, supporting both inbound and outbound scenarios.

Its main purpose is to help organizations design, standardize, and govern message structures and mappings in a reusable, scalable, and partner-independent manner, enabling consistent and efficient integration across multiple business partners.

Instead of building point-to-point mappings directly in iFlows in SAP Cloud Platform Integration, Integration Advisor introduces a model-driven approach based on:

  • MIG (Message Implementation Guideline) ‚Äì Defines message type content, select field by field from the message type.
  • MAG (Message Mapping Guideline) ‚Äì Defines mapping logic of fields.
  • TPM (Trading Partner Management) ‚Äì Assigns partners and agreements at runtime
    Since this is an exploratory blog, we will not go into TPM in depth and will focus only on its definition.

Roles and Responsibilities: MIG vs. MAG from a SAP CPI Developer Perspective:

One important point to highlight is that a SAP CPI developer should generally not be responsible for creating MIGs (Message Implementation Guidelines).

MIGs define the canonical data structure, including business fields, their semantic meaning, validation rules, and compliance with EDI standards. Creating a MIG requires deep business process knowledge and EDI expertise, typically provided by business analysts, functional consultants, or EDI specialists rather than technical integration developers.

From a SAP CPI developer‚Äôs point of view, it is technically possible to work with MIGs only if there is very clear and well-defined mapping documentation between the EDI standard and the SAP business objects. Without strong functional input, the risk of semantic errors is high‚Äîeven if the technical mapping itself is correct.

MAGs (Mapping Guidelines), on the other hand, are where the actual field-to-field mapping logic is implemented. This activity is comparable to traditional message mapping tasks already familiar to SAP CPI developers. It involves transforming source structures into target structures based on predefined rules, conditions, and conversions.

The Mapping Guidelines (MAGs) are designed to support standardized, declarative mappings and therefore do not support complex transformation logic.

MAGs are implemented using XSLT, which is well-suited for:

  • Straightforward field-to-field mappings
  • Simple value mappings and lookups
  • Basic conditional logic
  • Structural transformations

However, MAGs are not intended for complex business logic, such as:

  • Advanced conditional flows
  • Context XML node control
  • Loop Structures
  • Stateful processing
  • Cross-message correlations
  • Custom algorithms or calculations
  • Dynamic, runtime-driven transformations

This is precisely where a SAP CPI developer should be actively involved, as MAGs require strong technical integration skills, knowledge of SAP data models, and experience with transformation logic.

SAP Processes vs. EDI Standards ‚Äî A Practical Overview

In SAP B2B integration scenarios, the same business process can be represented by different EDI standards, depending on factors such as industry, geographical region, and trading partner requirements.

For example, a single SAP business process (such as Order-to-Cash or Procure-to-Pay) may be exchanged using different EDI formats across partners. This variability increases complexity and requires a structured approach to mapping and governance.

Below is a simplified overview that illustrates how SAP business processes can be mapped to multiple EDI message formats.

Business Context: Inbound EDI Integration into SAP

To simplify the explanation, I designed a single high-level diagram that illustrates the end-to-end inbound EDI flow, instead of presenting multiple step-by-step screenshots and low-level technical details.

Integration Advisor Design Approach

In SAP Integration Advisor (IA), the process starts with the definition of Message Implementation Guidelines (MIGs).
For an inbound integration scenario, two MIGs are required:

  1. Outbound MIG (from the external partner perspective)
  2. Inbound MIG ( to the SAP system perspective)

Use Case Description:

In this proof-of-concept, I am working with the EDI X12 message type 850 (Purchase Order), version 004010, including the envelope structure.

For this purpose, I created the following MIG for the external system:

  • MIG.ORDERPROCESS.X12.850.OUT

On the SAP inbound side, the target system is SAP S/4HANA On-Premise, using the IDoc message type ORDERS05 (related to ORDCHG/ORDERS processing).

I created the inbound MIG:

  • MIG.PROCESSORDERS.IDOC.ORDERS05.IN

Mapping Design (MAG)

After defining both MIGs, the next step is to create the Mapping Guideline (MAG).

  • Source: MIG.ORDERPROCESS.X12.850.OUT
  • Target: MIG.PROCESSORDERS.IDOC.ORDERS05.IN

Artifacts for SAP Cloud Integration:

Once the MAG is finalized, Integration Advisor generates a ZIP package or you can Inject direct from IA to SAP CPI Iflow that can be downloaded.This package contains all technical artifacts required for implementation in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI), including:

  • XSLT files (mapping logic)
  • XSL files
  • XSD schemas (source and target message structures)

Considering that this is an exploratory exercise, I will not perform end-to-end testing with an actual sending system and a receiving system.

It is important to mention that you can choose either to download the ZIP file or to directly inject the generated artifacts (XSDs and XSLTs) used by the MAG into SAP Cloud Integration directly from SAP Integration Advisor.

The final result will be an IDoc ORDCHG / ORDERS05, based on the simple mapping defined in the MAG  Mapping_MIG.ORDERPROCESS.X12.850.OUT_to_MIG.PROCESSORDERS.IDOC.ORDERS05.IN.

The image below demonstrates the test execution.

To simplify the explanation, the image below illustrates the Outbound MIG based on an EDI Flat File, the Inbound MIG based on an IDoc, and the MAG responsible for performing the field-level transformation between both message structures.

Proposed Scenario: EDI Integration Without Architectural Governance - SAP Integration Advisor

In this scenario, no definition or governance was provided by the SAP Integration Architecture or SAP Solution Architecture teams.
There was no strategic decision to organize or centralize EDI integrations using SAP Integration Advisor.

As a result:

  • No EDI governance model exists
  • No MIGs or MAGs were defined
  • No standardization or reuse of EDI structures
  • Each EDI integration is treated as an isolated, custom implementation

Direct Impact on the SAP CPI Developer:

Due to the lack of architectural definition, the SAP CPI Developer receives the following business requirement directly.

In practice, architectural and functional responsibilities are shifted to the technical layer.

The image below illustrates this scenario, in which SAP CPI was responsible for the entire end-to-end integration, without guidance or governance from SAP Integration Advisor, and still managed to successfully build the iFlow.

The difference between using a MAG (Mapping Guideline) and building a manual Message Mapping is significant and far more complex, as illustrated in the image below.

Conclusion from SAP CPI Developer Explorer:

It is important to clarify that this governance‚Äîincluding the definition of MIGs, MAGs, and especially TPM‚Äîis not the primary responsibility of an SAP CPI developer.

The Integration Advisor is a powerful tool for standardizing EDI, its success depends on solid architectural governance involving both Business and Architects.

Thank you.

Kind regards,

Viana.

entry.title: BehaviorInvocationException: Too few values in second queue in function useOneAsMany
entry.content:
Problem Statement

In SAP CPI Message Mapping, I faced a OneAsMany violation due to mismatched occurrences between two source fields:

  • Company Code ‚Üí Occurrence = 1

  • PRODUCTTAXITEM ‚Üí Occurrence = 2
    So basically, due to difference in context change, I was not able to use it in value mapping where the target field occurrence is also 2 times, due to this if i use it without OneasMany, it is throwing error : target field require value for it.

This resulted in the following OneAsMany rules being violated:

Rule 1: Input 1 should not contain repeating values in the same context.

Business requirement was to:

  • Increase the context of Company Code

  • Match it with the number of PRODUCTTAXITEM occurrences

  • Repeat only the first Company Code value for all PRODUCTTAXITEM contexts.

    Groovy code used is as follows:

    import com.sap.it.api.mapping.*

    // Function name must match the name used in Message Mapping UI
    def void replicateCompanyCode(
    String[] companyCode,
    String[] productTaxItem,
    Output companyCodeOut,
    MappingContext context) {

    // Guard checks
    if (companyCode == null || companyCode.length == 0 ||
    productTaxItem == null || productTaxItem.length == 0) {
    companyCodeOut.addSuppress()
    return
    }

    // Take only the first Company Code
    String firstCompanyCode = companyCode[0]

    // Create context based on PRODUCTTAXITEM count
    for (int i = 0; i < productTaxItem.length; i++) {
    companyCodeOut.addValue(firstCompanyCode)
    companyCodeOut.addContextChange()
    }
    }

entry.title: Train Joule AI for SAP ECC: Step-by-Step Guide: How to Create a Joule Skill for SAP ECC
entry.content:
INTRODUCTION

SAP Joule is SAP‚Äôs AI copilot that helps users perform business tasks using natural language. A Joule skill is a defined capability that allows Joule to answer questions or trigger actions in SAP systems.

SAP Joule is not natively built for direct integration with SAP ECC (Enterprise Core Component). It is primarily designed as a cloud native AI copilot for SAP's cloud solutions, such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP SuccessFactors.

However, customers on ECC can still leverage some of Joule's capabilities through hybrid approaches using the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).  This blog explains how to design and create a Joule skill that works with SAP ECC, using SAP‚Äôs recommended tools and architecture.

Step 1: Understand What a Joule Skill Is

A Joule skill consists of:

  • A user intent (what the user asks Joule)
  • Business logic (what happens behind the scenes)
  • System integration (ECC in this case)
  • A structured response back to the user

Example:

‚ÄúJoule, show me the open sales orders for top problematic customer ABC.‚Äù

Step 2: Identify the Use Case in SAP ECC

Start with a simple, high value use case.

Good examples

  • Check sales order status of top 5 customers
  • Customer 360 degree snapshots
  • Display open invoices
  • Get material stock levels
  • Which orders are delayed today?
  • Which materials are at risk this week?
  • What is product costing for X product in last 5 years? Where am I spending more money?

Define clearly:

  • What data is needed from ECC
  • Which transaction or table provides it
  • Whether it‚Äôs read only or triggers an action

Why it‚Äôs great:

  • Sales + Finance or Procurement+Finance in one answer
  • Simple answers to today's painful questions
  • Very executive-friendly and great for planners without systems

Step 3: Prepare SAP ECC for Integration

Joule does not connect directly to ECC. You need an API layer.

Common integration options:

  • OData services (via SAP Gateway)
  • RFC / BAPI exposed through SAP Integration Suite
  • IDocs (less common for Joule)

Actions:

  1. Identify the ECC function module or BAPI
  2. Expose it as an OData service or API
  3. Test the API independently

Example:

  • BAPI_SALESORDER_GETSTATUS
  • BAPI_CUSTOMER_GETDETAIL

Step 4: Set Up SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)

Joule skills are built and orchestrated on SAP BTP. You will need:

  • SAP BTP account
  • SAP Integration Suite
  • SAP Build Process Automation or Build Apps
  • SAP AI Core / AI Launchpad (if using advanced AI logic)

Ensure:

  • ECC is connected securely to BTP
  • Authentication (OAuth / Principal Propagation) is configured

Step 5: Create the Business Logic (Skill Backend)

Now you define what the skill actually does.

Options:

  • SAP Build Process Automation (recommended)
  • SAP Build Apps
  • CAP (Cloud Application Programming) model

Steps:

  1. Create a process or service
  2. Consume the ECC API
  3. Map input parameters (e.g., customer number)
  4. Format the output clearly for Joule

Example output:

  • Sales order number
  • Status
  • Delivery date

Step 6: Define the Joule Skill (Intent)

This is where Joule learns how users talk.

You define:

  • Skill name
  • User intent
  • Sample phrases

Examples:

  • ‚ÄúShow open sales orders for customer 10001‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWhat is the status of sales order 4500001234?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúCheck customer ABC orders‚Äù

These help Joule understand variations in natural language.

Step 7: Connect Joule to the Backend Logic

Now connect:

  • The user intent
  • To the backend service or process

Actions:

  • Map extracted parameters (order number, customer ID)
  • Trigger the ECC API call
  • Capture the response
  • Return structured data to Joule

Step 8: Design the Response Experience

Joule responses should be:

  • Short
  • Clear
  • Actionable

Examples:

  • Text summary
  • Bullet points
  • Table Style

Bad response:

‚ÄúHere is the data you requested.‚Äù

Good response:

‚ÄúCustomer ABC has 3 open sales orders. The next delivery is scheduled for 12 Oct.‚Äù

Step 9: Test the Joule Skill

Testing is critical.

Test scenarios:

  • Valid and Invalid input
  • Missing parameters
  • Incorrect values
  • No data found
  • Performance delays

Test in:

  • SAP Joule preview
  • BTP logs
  • ECC backend logs

Step 10: Secure and Authorize the Skill

Ensure:

  • Only authorized users can access ECC data
  • Role based access is enforced
  • Sensitive fields are masked if needed

Use:

  • SAP Identity Authentication (IAS)
  • Role collections in BTP
  • ECC authorization objects

Step 11: Deploy and Enable for Users

Once tested:

  1. Deploy the backend service
  2. Activate the Joule skill
  3. Assign it to user roles
  4. Enable it in the SAP application where Joule is use

Step 12: Monitor and Improve

After go live:

  • Monitor usage
  • Review failed queries
  • Expand to new ECC use cases

Over time, Joule becomes smarter and more valuable.

What works?

Creating a Joule skill for SAP ECC involves:

  • Clear business use cases
  • API based ECC integration
  • SAP BTP orchestration
  • Well designed natural language interaction

While ECC is a legacy system, Joule allows it to be used in a modern, conversational way.

entry.title: How to Access SAP Cloud Logging Service Dashboards Using IAS SAML Authentication
entry.content:
Japanese version

Introduction

SAP Cloud Logging Service (CLS) is an OpenSearch-based observability service that allows you to centrally manage application logs and metrics.

Because CLS Dashboards provide access to application data such as logs and metrics, proper security measures such as authentication methods and access control are essential.

Although CLS Dashboards can be accessed using a Service Key, SAP recommends using SAML authentication with IAS in production environments to ensure proper user management and stronger security.

In this article, we walk through the configuration steps required to enable SAML authentication for CLS Dashboards using IAS.

Prerequisites

This guide assumes the following conditions are met:

  • An IAS tenant is active
  • SAP Cloud Logging Service is available in your SAP BTP subaccount
  • You have administrator privileges for both IAS and the BTP subaccount

Step 1: Create a SAML 2.0 Application in IAS

In the IAS administration application, navigate to Applications & Resources ‚Üí Applications, and create a new application.

  • Display Name: Any name
  • Protocol Type: SAML 2.0

Step 2: Create a CLS Instance and Configure SAML

If you already have an existing CLS instance, you can update its parameters in the same way as during instance creation.

In this article, we describe the steps using a new CLS instance.

2-1. Create a CLS Instance

Create a CLS instance in your BTP subaccount.

  • Service: Cloud Logging
  • Plan / Runtime Environment: Choose according to your use case
  • Instance Name: Any name

After entering the values, click Next to proceed to the parameter configuration screen.

2-2. Configure SAML Parameters

The default parameters will be displayed. Edit the saml section as shown below.

Default parameters

Updated parameters

{
  "saml": {
    "enabled": true,
    "admin_group": "<IAS_ADMIN_GROUP_NAME>",
    "initiated": true,
    "roles_key": "groups",
    "idp": {
      "metadata_url": "<IAS_TENANT_URL>/saml2/metadata",
      "entity_id": "<IAS_IDP_ENTITY_ID>"
    },
    "sp": {
      "entity_id": "<CLS_SP_ENTITY_ID>"
    }
  }
}

saml section template

Parameter Explanation

admin_group
Users who belong to the specified IAS group are granted administrator privileges (all_access).
In this example, we use cls-admin.

idp.metadata_url
The URL from which CLS retrieves SAML metadata from IAS.
Append /saml2/metadata to your IAS tenant URL.
For example, if your IAS tenant URL is:
https://<YOUR-TENANT-NAME>.accounts400.ondemand.com

then set:
https://<YOUR-TENANT-NAME>.accounts400.ondemand.com/saml2/metadata

idp.entity_id
Open the metadata_url in a browser and set the value of 'entityID' found at the beginning of the XML.

sp.entity_id
The identifier for CLS as a Service Provider. In this example, we use 'CLS-Demo'. The same value must be configured on the IAS side.

Step 3: Configure SAML Settings in IAS

In the IAS application settings, select Configure Manually and configure the SAML settings.

  • Entity ID: Same value as 'sp.entity_id' of the CLS instance

This ID uniquely identifies CLS as the Service Provider in the SAML integration.
Since we used 'CLS-Demo'in the CLS configuration, the same value must be set here.

Endpoint Configuration

  • SSO Endpoint: <Dashboards URL>/_opendistro/_security/saml/acs

  • Single Logout Endpoint: <Dashboards URL>

Verification (Authentication)

Access the CLS Dashboards URL and confirm that authentication succeeds.

At this point, when opening dashboards or index lists, you may see a blank page or permission-related errors.

In Developer Tools, you can also confirm that HTTP 403 (Forbidden) responses are returned.

If you click View roles and identities from the user icon, you will see that only the 'own_index' role is assigned.

This indicates that SAML authentication is working correctly, but authorization (role assignment) has not yet been configured.

Step 4: Configure Attributes in the IAS Application

To use IAS group information for role assignment in CLS, group data must be included in the SAML assertion.

Open Attributes in the IAS application and configure the following:

  • Name: groups
  • Source: Identity Directory
  • Values: All Groups

Step 5: Create a Group and Add Users

Create a user group in IAS with the same name as the 'admin_group' configured in Step 2.
In this example, the group name is 'cls-admin'.

  • Name: Same as 'admin_group'

  • Display Name: Any name

Add the target users to the group.

 

Verification (Authorization)

Access the dashboard page again and confirm that the list of dashboard is now visible.

You can also verify that the 'all_access' role has been assigned to the user via the 'cls_admin' group.


I hope this article helps you with application development and operations on SAP BTP!!

References

  • https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-logging/cloud-logging/prerequisites
  • https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-logging/cloud-logging/configuration-parameters

entry.title: Push UUID from IAS to S4HANA - Tasks list on BTP task Center is empty for S4HANA
entry.content:
Introduction:

After completing all prerequisites and following the SAP documentation to configure the Task Center for an SAP S/4HANA system, it is quite common to encounter a situation where no tasks are displayed in the Task Center‚Äîeven though task creation appears to be working correctly in the backend.

This blog addresses one of the most frequently overlooked root causes behind this issue: the absence of a Global User ID (UUID) in the SAP S/4HANA system. Even when the Task Center is correctly configured on SAP BTP and tasks are visible in the pull cache, missing UUID mapping can prevent the Task Center from resolving the processor correctly, resulting in an empty Task Center UI.

In this blog, I will walk you through a critical but often missed step required to ensure tasks are displayed correctly in the Task Center. The focus is on establishing a one-way synchronization from SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS) to SAP S/4HANA to push the UUIDs for existing users, without performing a full user provisioning or re-synchronization.

Solution:

Even after configuring the Task Center on HANA on-premise and completing all required steps on BTP, the Task Center may appear empty, as shown in the screenshot below.

When you check the Task Center pull cache, you can see that the task exists; however, it is still not displayed in the Task Center app. As shown in the screenshot below, the task appears with the processor name set to the SAP user ID. This situation occurs when a GUID (UUID) is not available in the SAP HANA system. In such cases, the system falls back to using the SAP user ID instead of the UUID. As a result, the Task Center is unable to correctly resolve the processor, and the task is not displayed in the Task Center app.

To resolve this issue, we need to ensure that a UUID is available in the SAP system. The steps to achieve this are explained below. Before updating the UUID in the SAP HANA system, the user profile in the SU01 screen appears as shown in the screenshot below.
SU01-->Goto-->External User ID(UID)

Please note that in this scenario, we are not synchronizing SAP users to IAS and then syncing the UUID back to the HANA system. Since the UUIDs and users already exist in IAS as a result of the SuccessFactors integration, we will establish a one-way synchronization from IAS to SAP S/4HANA solely to push the UUID into the system

To push the UUID (Global User ID) to SAP system please follow below steps.


Prerequisite:
1.  Login to your Cloud Connector: Make sure your Cloud connectors connection from BTP to HANA has access to below BAPI/FM 

  • PRGN_ROLE_GETLIST
  • BAPI_USER_GETLIST
  • BAPI_USER_GET_DETAIL
  • BAPI_USER_CREATE1
  • BAPI_USER_ACTGROUPS_ASSIGN
  • IDENTITY_MODIFY
  • BAPI_USER_DELETE
  • PRGN_ACTIVITY_GROUPS_LOAD_RFC

2. Create a technical user in SAP HANA, or reuse an existing technical user that is used to pull tasks for the Task Center. Ensure that this user is assigned the required role listed below. This technical user will be used to create the RFC destination in the BTP subaccount, which will later be used to create the target system in IAS

  • SAP_BC_JSF_COMMUNICATION

3. Create a RFC destination on the BTP account where your IAS is hosted by referring to below SAP guide.
https://help.sap.com/docs/connectivity/sap-btp-connectivity-cf/create-rfc-destinations

Note: If you prefer to create the RFC destination in a different subaccount - perhaps within the same sub account as SAP Work Zone or the Task Center- ensure that you create an Identity Access Management (IAM) service instance in that subaccount. This is required so that the RFC destination you create is visible in the IAS administration console.

After completing the prerequisites, log in to IAS and create the source and destination systems to perform the push.

Creating Source system: Because the users are already available in IAS, select Local Identity Directory as the source system.
Creating the Source system is straightforward.

Also, The Task Center pull cache will have UUID for the processor field instead of the SAP user name and Tasks will be shown in the Task center as below.

 

Conclusion:

An empty Task Center‚Äîdespite correct backend task creation and successful pull cache entries‚Äîcan be misleading and time-consuming to troubleshoot. As demonstrated in this blog, the root cause is often the absence of a UUID in the SAP S/4HANA user master, which prevents the Task Center from resolving the task processor correctly.

By ensuring that the Global User ID (UUID) is pushed from IAS to SAP S/4HANA through a one-way synchronization, this issue can be resolved effectively without impacting existing user provisioning or SuccessFactors integrations. Once the UUID is updated in the SU01 user profile, the Task Center pull cache correctly reflects the UUID, and tasks become visible in the Task Center application as expected.

I hope this blog helps you avoid common pitfalls during Task Center setup and saves valuable troubleshooting time. Feel free to share your feedback or experiences, and happy learning!

entry.title: SAP BTP - APIM - Demystified: Designing a Single API Proxy with Dynamic Routing for Multiple Targets
entry.content:
Introduction

In modern enterprise landscapes, APIs are no longer simple pass-through interfaces; they are strategic assets that must support multiple backends, environment segregation, multi-tenant scenarios, and dynamic routing‚Äîall while remaining secure, observable, and maintainable.

Within the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), SAP API Management plays a critical role as the security and governance layer for backend systems like SAP Integration Suite (CPI), S/4HANA, ECC, Fieldglass, Concur, and various external applications.

In this blog, I present a common enterprise requirement: designing a single security layer that acts as a shield for SAP CPI, handling access control, host protection, and traffic governance. I will demonstrate how to build a single API Proxy with dynamic routing capabilities, allowing multiple iFlow endpoints to be managed through one centralized entry point.

This approach eliminates the need for hundreds of individual proxies, keeps the APIM cockpit organized, and significantly simplifies monitoring. Whether you are a beginner following the step-by-step visuals or a senior consultant jumping straight to the "Checkmate" strategy at the end, this guide is designed for all levels of expertise.

üóùÔ∏è The check-mate secret will be revealed at the end.üóùÔ∏è

To illustrate the introduction, please check the image below:

Figure 1 - Integration Prespective

Summary of the image:

  1. Consumer ‚Üí calls ‚Üí API Proxy (in SAP APIM)
  2. API Proxy (Apply Policies) ‚Üí forwards to ‚Üí API Provider (SAP CPI- Multiples Iflows from the SAP package)
  3. SAP CPI  ‚Üí processes logic ‚Üí Any Backend ( SAP on-prem/SAP on-cloud/External App)

Let‚Äôs move forward together and break down the concepts step by step.

Before we get hands-on, let‚Äôs take a short theoretical detour to clearly understand what each object is responsible for.

What is an API Proxy ?

Think of the proxy as a Security and Governance Layer. While the backend provides the data, the proxy provides

  • Security: Enforces OAuth, Basic Authentication, API Keys Header, or SQL injection protection.
  • Traffic Control: Sets rate limits (e.g., 100 calls per minute) to protect your backend from crashing.
  • Transformation: Converts data formats (e.g., SOAP to REST or XML to JSON) without changing the backend code.
  • Analytics: Tracks who is using the API and how often.

What is API provider ?

An API Provider is a centralized configuration in SAP APIM that defines the connection details, authentication, and location of a backend system, such as SAP S/4HANA or SAP CPI.

Instead of hard-coding URLs into every individual proxy, you create a Provider once to act as a reusable gateway to that system‚Äôs entire service catalog.

This "clean" approach allows you to automatically discover services and update backend settings in one single place without breaking your existing API proxies.

Can SAP CPI be an API Provider?

Yes, absolutely. In fact, this is a very common "best practice" in the SAP Integration Suite.

  • SAP CPI (Cloud Integration) is the Execution Engine: It handles the complex logic, data mapping, and connecting to multiple systems.
  • SAP APIM is the Governance Layer: It handles the exposure of that CPI flow to the outside world

From Concept to Implementation

We‚Äôve talked the talk ‚Äî now it‚Äôs time to make these APIs working.

Our Mission Together

Build a Multi-Target Mega-Proxy:

  • One front door (API Proxy)
  • Smart enough to check the visitor‚Äôs ‚ÄúID‚Äù (headers, basic authentication, mask host)
  • Routes requests dynamically to different CPI iFlows based on the HTTP path

I'm going to cross together with you in phases:

  • Phase 1: The "Secret Agents" (Setting up Providers)
  • Phase 2: The "Master Architect" (Creating the Proxy)
  • Phase 3: The "Split Personality" (Adding the Second Target)
  • Phase 4: The "The Routing Gate for Heaven" (Time to setup the routing mechanism)
  • Phase 5: The "Dangerous Security Zone" (Applying the Shields)

Phase 1: The "Secret Agents" (Setting up Providers)

Before we build the bridge, we need to know where the islands are.

  1. Go to your APIM Portal and hit the Configure icon (the little gears).

  2. Create your first Agent (API Provider): Let‚Äôs call it SAPCPI.

    1.  

      Type: Choose Cloud Integration.
    2. Host: Paste your CPI tenant runtime URL (leave out the https:// - just the hostname).

  3. Save & Test: Click that "Test Connection" button. If it turns green, you‚Äôre a genius. If it turns yellow HTTP 400, you as CPI developer know the reason, the connection is working don't worry.

Figure 2 - API Provider - SAP CPI Configured

Phase 2: The "Master Architect" (Creating the Proxy)

Now, let's build the Proxy that will rule them all, as you can see API proxy can be generated with API provider, API Proxy or URL. To keep very organized and clean governance, use API Provider or API proxy as clone the URL I don't recommend, just for POC that's ok.

  1. Develop ‚Üí APIs ‚Üí Create
  2. The Choice: Select API Provider.
    Pick SAPCPI. 
  3. URL: /
  4. The Name (My recommendation, use the same CPI Package name as reference): Call it PackageSAPSCNBlog.
  5. Host alias: <hostname.your.sap.apim>
  6. API base path ( you can add what ever you want, just as suggestion): /sapcpi/

Figure 3 - Creating the proxy with API provider

Phase 3: The "Split Personality" (Adding the Second Target)

By default, your proxy only knows about CPI. Let's give it a second destination.

  1. Open your new Proxy and go to the Target Endpoints tab.
  2. Click the + (Add) button.
  3. Name it (I recomend the name of Iflow to mantain organized): .<IflowName>

  4. The Magic Link: provide the path generate in SAP CPI, in this case /http/cpi/IflowA.

    • Now your Proxy has two exits, but it doesn't know which one to use yet!

Figure 3 - Create TargetEndpoint

After you generate the target endpoints, you are going to see something like this:

Figure 4 - Multiples Target Endpoints

Phase 4: The "The Routing Gate for Heaven (Time to setup the routing mechanism)

  1. The Choice: ProxyEndPoint
  2. Add the routing rules based on path of SAP CPI endpoint sample based on this blog
    1. IflowA -  proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/http/cpi/IflowA"
    2. IflowB  - proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/http/cpi/IflowB"
    3. IflowC - proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/http/cpi/IflowC"
    4. IflowD -  proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/http/cpi/IflowD"
    5. IflowE -   proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath "/http/cpi/IflowE"
    6.  
  3. In this point you can delete the router - default

Figure 5 - Multiples Variable Runtime - proxy.pathsuffix MatchesPath

Phase 5: The "Dangerous Security Zone" (Applying the Shields - Policies)

To solve the Chess Puzzle of APIM, you have to understand the "Timeline" of a request. A single API call is like a round-trip train journey. The request goes in through the Proxy and out to the Target, then the response comes back from the Target and out through the Proxy.

The PreFlow and PostFlow are the "Stations" where you can plug in your policies.

Proxy Endpoint (The Front Door)

This is where the client (Postman, Mobile App) interacts with APIM.

  • PreFlow: This happens first. It is the best place for Security (API Key, OAuth) and Spike Arrest. If the "visitor" is dangerous, you kick them out here before they waste any more of your system's energy.
  • PostFlow: This happens last, just before the response is sent back to the client. It‚Äôs perfect for Logging or clean-up.

Target Endpoint (The Back Door)

This is where APIM interacts with your backend.

  • PreFlow: This happens right before the request hits your backend. It is the best place for Transformation (adding a specific header the backend needs) or URL Rewriting.
  • PostFlow: This happens right after the backend responds but before it goes back to the Proxy. This is where you might Format JSON or remove sensitive backend headers.

So in the Proxy Endpoint - Preflow I added some security and custom messages replay as you can see in the image below:

Figure 6 - Security Policies - Proxy Endpoing Pre-flow

These are basic policies; for your project, you could add Spike Arrest, OAuth2 validation, and Credential Buffering, but since the focus isn't on complex policies right now, let's stick to the foundational ones.

  1. Step 1: Java script check header
  2. Step 2: Fault custom message response
  3. Step 3: Standard Basic Authentication - Here you need to change the XML from encode to decode
  4. Step 4:Java script security header
  5. Step5: Java script check credentials
  6. Step 6: Fault custom message response - In case of user/pass is empty or different from API Provider - SAP CPI
  7. Step 7: Java Script Set host

In case that you want custom the Fault message, because the standard one it's really technical and if you create something custom will helps more your consumers.

Figure 7 - Custom replay Fault exception

  • Step 2: Fault custom message response
<RaiseFault continueOnError="false"
            enabled="true"
            xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">

    <FaultResponse>
        <Set>
            <Headers>
                <Header name="Content-Type">application/json</Header>
            </Headers>

            <Payload contentType="application/json">
            {
              "Error": "HTTP 500 - Internal Server Error",
              "Detail": "(Basic Authtentication - User/Password) is required to access this API."
            }
            </Payload>

            <StatusCode>500</StatusCode>
            <ReasonPhrase>Internal Server Error</ReasonPhrase>
        </Set>
    </FaultResponse>

    <IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>true</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>

</RaiseFault>
  • Step 6: Fault custom message response - In case of user/pass is empty or different from API Provider - SAP CPI
<RaiseFault continueOnError="false" enabled="true"
            xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">

    <FaultResponse>
        <Set>
            <Headers>
                <Header name="Content-Type">application/json</Header>
            </Headers>
            <Payload contentType="application/json">
            {
              "error": "HTTP 401 Unauthorized",
              "message": "Invalid username or password.The credentials can not be empty value."
            }
            </Payload>
            <StatusCode>401</StatusCode>
            <ReasonPhrase>Unauthorized</ReasonPhrase>
        </Set>
    </FaultResponse>
</RaiseFault>

Full java script - Main.js - I decide create in this way to also keep organized and centralized all functions in one place instead of create one java script per function.

//Check the Check Header
function handleSecurityHeader() {
var authHeader = context.getVariable("request.header.Authorization");

if (!authHeader) {
    context.setVariable("auth.header.missing", true);
} else {
    context.setVariable("auth.header.missing", false);
}
}

//Validation of user/pass
function handleCredentialCheck() {

var user = context.getVariable("basic.username");
var pass = context.getVariable("basic.password");

// DEBUG
context.setVariable("username", user);
context.setVariable("pass", pass);

if (!user || !pass) {
    context.setVariable("auth.failed", true);
} else if (user !== "<SAP CPI USER PROVIDED>" || pass !== "<SAP CPI PASSWORD PROVIDED>") {
    context.setVariable("auth.failed", false);
}
}

//Mask Address
function handleResponseMasking() {
    var rc = context.getVariable("response.content");
    
    if (rc) {
        var targetHost = context.getVariable("target.host");
        var proxyHost = context.getVariable("proxy.host");
        var targetBase = context.getVariable("target.basepath");
        var proxyBase = context.getVariable("proxy.basepath");

        var maskedResponse = rc;

        // Mask the Hostname
        if (targetHost && proxyHost) {
            // 'g' means global (replace all), 'i' means case-insensitive
            var hostRegex = new RegExp(targetHost.toString(), 'gi');
            maskedResponse = maskedResponse.replace(hostRegex, proxyHost.toString());
        }

        // Mask the Base Path
        if (targetBase && proxyBase) {
            var baseRegex = new RegExp(targetBase.toString(), 'gi');
            maskedResponse = maskedResponse.replace(baseRegex, proxyBase.toString());
        } 

        // Update the response content and the custom variable
        context.setVariable("target.host",maskedResponse)
        context.setVariable("response.content", maskedResponse);
        context.setVariable("masked.targeturl", maskedResponse);
    }
}

//Routing mechanism
function RoutingCpiEndpoint() {
    
var suffix = context.getVariable("proxy.pathsuffix");
if (suffix == null) {
    suffix = "";
}

var targetBase = "<SAP CPI ADDRESS>";

// Use the + operator for compatibility
var finalUrl = targetBase.toString() + suffix.toString();

// Set it back to a context variable so the target can use it
context.setVariable("target.url", finalUrl);

}

 //Sets the proxy host in the proxyendpoint preflow so that it can be used later on
function setProxyHost(){
  var host = context.proxyRequest.headers['host'];
  context.setVariable("apim.proxyHost", host);
}

The visual with this organization, the fact you also will create the Main.js, you need to generate the others java scripts, as suggestion create with name convention JS-Exe(function)

Figure 8 - JavaScript Main and Java Script excetion

After that you can click in Java script in the Policy and add in the steps, but how to configure the XML ? Check below:

<IncludeURL>jsc://JS-Main.js</IncludeURL> - Include the JS-Main.js
